intro: Carex incrassata, commonly known as the broad-leaf sedge, is a perennial plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, grass-like leaves and spike-like flower clusters. Native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically wind-pollinated. It is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and support aquatic ecosystems.
